I HAS SOMETHING IMPORTANT TO TELLS YOU
Btw. I wanted to let you know
Before you try taking on Gundyr again, download the Watchdog mod for DS3
Watchdog mod? What does that do?
It's a way to detect / prevent / kick hackers during your sessions
Good idea then, I'll download it when I try it
DS3 USED to have Family Share, which was a workaround for Fromsoft's lazy anti-cheat / customer service
Might try it Sunday or Monday
Though, since they removed family share, they're willing to unban people more than once
But this just lets you avoid the annoyance and headaches and potentially needing to delete characters
That last bit is the big one
Script kiddies can inject your character with invalid gestures / items that can't be removed through normal means, and those things can set off the anti-cheat and softban you

That said, watched a funny vid where a script kiddie tried injecting a BUNCH of invalid items to a guy, and then trying to kill him with a "cursed" straight sword, and then being SUPER confused when nothing happened :ptv-laugh:
All they have to do is take the Watchdog mod and bake it into the game
And boom, their shitty cheating problem is basically null and void
Btw, I found the most "I don't care" hacker ever
Watchdog was like "WARNING, REAL SL DOES NOT MATCH GAME'S DETECTED SL"
Guy was listed as 34, but his "real" level was 35 :ptv-snicker:
I'm like, "*GASP* I CAN'T BELIEVE THIS ATROCITY! HE SHALL PAY FOR THIS! *presses ignore hotkey to turn off warning*" :ptv-laugh:

we used to play with all sorts of custom rules to make our D&D games more interesting
A person could be using a giant slab of metal the size of a person as a weapon
so what is your wizard's low stat?
we determined that just rolling 4d6-L  stats really just made... average characters
But at the same time be smart enough to use intricate spells or zealous enough to throw lightning bolts
so we started letting peopel roll 4d6-L to get their total stat 'pool' and then adjust anything up or down by 2 as long as the total stayed the same
and it made for much more variety
I started with 3D6. It's still my favorite for just taking what you get and working with it.
just a house rule, but the point of tabletop gaming is to have fun
and it made it more fun for the group hehe
for higher power games we would do Roll 4d6-LRR1's 8 times
it lets you get away from 'stereotype' builds too
'wizard always has crap strength and constitution'
Point buy is interesting, but kinda restrictive. I get why it exists, but I like random results.
